options.text: A medical condition that affects vision

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, why does our brain compensate for the perceived difference in brightness between the two tiles in the checkerboard illusion?

options.text: Because our brain is trying to compensate for the perceived difference in brightness based on context

options.label: D
options.text: Because our brain is ignoring the surrounding environment

options.text: That our brain is trying to create a sense of confusion

options.label: C
options.text: That our brain is ignoring the surrounding environment

options.label: D

title: 6 ways to start a sentence | Sentence structure | Learn to write

multiple-choice.question: What is the subject of a sentence?

options.label: A
options.text: A word that tells you what the subject is doing

options.label: B
options.text: A person, place, thing, or idea

options.label: C
options.text: A verb that tells you where the subject is happening

options.label: D
options.text: A word that tells you when the subject is happening

multiple-choice.question: How can you start a sentence to explain where something happens?

options.label: C
options.text: With words that tell you where something is happening

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of asking a question in a sentence?

options.label: A
options.text: To tell the reader what to do

options.label: B
options.text: To tell the reader where something is happening

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of an -ing phrase used to start a sentence?

options.label: B
options.text: "Looking at the clock, she realized she was going to be late"

options.label: D
options.text: "Frightened by the loud fireworks, the dog hid under the table"

multiple-choice.question: What is the function of a comma when using an -ing or -ed word to start a sentence?

options.label: B
options.text: To separate two ideas in a sentence

options.label: C
options.text: To separate an introductory word from the rest of the sentence

options.label: D
options.text: To separate a subject from a verb

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of an adverb used to start a sentence?

options.label: B
options.text: "Looking at the clock, she realized she was going to be late"

options.label: C
options.text: "Carefully, she tiptoed past the sleeping monster"

options.label: D
options.text: "Frightened by the loud fireworks, the dog hid under the table"

multiple-choice.question: Why is it important to add a plan to your writing?

options.label: B
options.text: To reduce the fear of writing

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of using a subject first and a verb second to start a sentence?

options.label: C
options.text: To put the main idea first

options.label: D
options.text: To make the sentence more interesting

multiple-choice.question: How can using adverbs like "carefully" or "hungrily" affect the reader?

options.label: A
options.text: They can make the reader think

options.label: B
options.text: They can make the reader laugh

options.label: C
options.text: They can create a vivid image in the reader's mind

options.label: D
options.text: They can make the reader bored

multiple-choice.question: What is the main benefit of using the six methods discussed in the video?

options.label: B
options.text: To reduce the fear of writing
